content.description: Hard moves to and over a roof then angles up and right to a thin crack.
content.location: Left of route that starts up a short crack.

content.description: This route overhangs 10 feet in 30.  Hard climbing from the start to a good shake then deceptively hard laybacking on steep stuff leads to a few easier moves to the chains.  This may be a little bit of a reach (power) problem as I (5.6) deadpoint the crux.  I did the moves as we worked it on TR before bolting it but couldn't redpoint it despite 15 or so attempts.  Jimbo nailed it second go.  Whether it is a reach problem or not he is now a giant in my eyes.
content.location: West face of It Wall.  Go down hill then around corner and up a little.

content.description:
The Crux as with the others on this wall is getting over the bulge.  There is a trick for those who don't live on a campus board and the name was inspired by a guy who is always on his heels. 

  This route gets very close to the roof to the left of it as you turn the roof.
content.location: Starts in a thin crack that allows you to step up on a small wedged boulder.

climbs.name: We Aren't Going to Take It
climbs.fa: Eric Ruljancich, Pete Piek, Lora Rivera, Michael Swanberg

content.description:
A fun, short and bouldery addition to the cliff.  You may feel the grade clocks in a bit higher or lower depending on your bouldering prowess or lack thereof.  

  Be careful between bolts 2 and 3 as there is still some rock that is eroding.   

  The name is a multi level play on the name of the cliff, hang dogging, an awesome 80s song, and my feelings on the current political situation in the US.
content.location: Just left of the Cousin It, the 5.9 arete warm up.  You can easily hang draws from the 5.9

content.description: Hard to believe from looking at this that it could be so good but it is.  You will find the moves interesting and your forearms begging for mercy.
content.location: Starts with easy climbing up to a ledge at the top of a stair stepped flake.  Then working up corner (without a crack in the back).

climbs.name: Something Else
climbs.fa: Original: EFR, John Hayes 1986  Retro-bolt: EFR 2013

content.description: Climb orange/white face just right of a crack. While now a fully bolted sport route, the crack behind the ledge 10' up supposedly takes gear well.
content.protection: The original route was retro-bolted by the FA.  This route is now entirely bolt protected.  The anchors are leaver biners.

content.description: This thing is so short that it is easily discounted as too short to bother with.  However, it is really a blast and it will work you to the anchors.
content.location: On the left end of the wall this route heads up a small corner left of the arete.

content.description: Shares start with Something Else, but quickly moves up and right.
content.location: Second route from right end of face.

content.description: Laybacking up a crack to a ledge then fun face climbing and a good finish.
content.location: Far right end of the wall. Start up short crack which leads to a ledge on the west face.

content.description: Attention all crack climbers...this one is a Lemmon gem.  A high quality crack that eats up gear and has got to be one of the few cracks of its kind on the mountain.

climbs.name: Another Thing
climbs.fa: TR: Eric Fazio-Rhicard & Cyrena Goodrich (1986)  Retrobolt: Eric Fazio-Rhicard & Jim Scott (2013)

content.description: Climb red face to corner.  Let me know if you have more info; I'll add it.
content.protection: The original route was retro-bolted by the FA. This route is now entirely bolt protected. The anchors are leaver biners.
content.location: Left of the chimney that is left of It Crack

content.description: Overhanging face.   I hear the holds are sharp...
content.location: Farthest right climb on the face.

content.description: A small little overhanging rock with high quality routes.  A nice area in any weather...even rain.  While here, enjoy one of Mount Lemmon's finest cracks in "It Crack."
